text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity: The Amniotes. Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes.  Introduction to the amniotes – Reptiles – Birds – Mammals Recap: Amniotes are tetrapods that have a terrestrially adapted egg Extant amniotes  Reptiles & birds  Mammals Derived amniote characteristics  Amniotic egg  4 extraembryonic membranes  Amnion, chorion, yolk sac, allantois  Amniotic eggs of most reptiles & some mammals - shell http://tolweb.org/Amniota Recap: The Amniotic egg.  Colonization land by vertebrates.  Amniote - extra-embryonic membranes  Not found in anamniote vertebrates (fish & amphibia).  Evolutionary reasons unclear – increased size & strength. http://tolweb.org/Amniota The Amniotic egg. Biological engineering!  Protection – shell - leathery / calcified.  Respiration – shell – gases & water.  Respiration – amnion & chorion vascularized.  Respiration/excretion – allantois – vascularized.  Nutrition/protection – albumen.  Nutrition – egg yolk. http://tolweb.org/Amniota Other adaptations for life on land  Rib cage to ventilate lungs. – More efficient than throat-based ventilation. – Amphibians use method to supplement respiration via skin.  Did increased efficiency rib cage ventilation allow amniotes to abandon respiration via skin? – Less permeable skin? – Water conservation? Early amniotes  Most recent common ancestor living amphibians & amniotes ~ 370 MYA.  No amniotic egg fossils. Evidence from amniote fossils – Could live in drier climates than 1st tetrapods – Some herbivores – grinding teeth. – Some predators. Reptiles (Reptilia)  Reptile clade includes: – Extant tuataras, lizards, snakes, turtles, crocodilians & birds – Extinct e.g. pleisiosaurs & ichthyosaurs  Extant reptile lineages highly derived – no straightforward model for earliest reptiles (320 MYA) – but comparative analyses some derived characters http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizar ds-new- zealand/tuatara/tuatara.htm https://www.floridamuseum.u fl.edu/event/world-sea-turtle- day/ http://www.okbirds.com/?cat=29 https://www.thegoavilla.co m/goa/distanation/goa- crocodiles.html https://www .floridamuse um.ufl.edu/h erpetology/fl - snakes/visua l-id/ Reptiles  Derived characters  Scales – keratin – Protection – abrasion & desiccation  Most reptiles - shelled eggs on land.  Internal fertilisation – before egg shell secreted.  Many viviparous sp. http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizar ds-new- zealand/tuatara/tuatara.htm https://www.thegoavilla.com/goa/dista nation/goa-crocodiles.html http://www.okbirds.com/?cat=29 https://www.floridamuseum.ufl.edu/her petology/fl-snakes/visual-id/ Reptiles  Ectothermic – – Not metabolic thermoregulation – behavioural  Reptile survive ~10% energy required by mammal of same size.  Reptile clade not entirely ectothermic – Birds – endothermic – maintain body temperature - metabolic activity. https://www.thegoavilla.com/goa/distanation/goa- crocodiles.html http://www.okbirds.com/?cat=29 Reptiles  Oldest reptilian fossils – late Carboniferous ~310 MYA.  Parareptiles – Large, stocky, quadrupedal herbivores – Some plated – defence – Extinct end Triassic ~200MYA.  As parareptiles dwindling diapsid clade diversifying. http://palaeos.com/vertebrates/anapsida/pareiasaurid ae3.html Diapsids Most obvious derived diapsid character – Pair holes each side skull behind eye socket 2 main lineages of diapsids  Lepidosaurs – Extant tuataras, lizards & snakes – Extinct marine reptiles e.g. giant mososaurs  Archosaurs – crocodilians, Pterosaurs & dinosaurs http://slideplayer.com/slide/8170671/ Dinosaurs (Archosaurs)  On land dinosaurs diversified 2 main lineages  Ornithischians – Herbivores – many with elaborate anti- predator defences  tail clubs & horned crests  Saurischians – Long-necked giant tree browsers – Theropods – bipedal carnivores – including Tyrannosaurus rex & bird ancestors http://www.nhm.ac.uk/discove r/dino- directory/name/t/gallery.html http://www.nhm.ac.uk/discove r/dino- directory/name/t/gallery.html Lepidosaurs 2 extant lineages  Sphenodontians - Tuataras – Lizard-like reptiles – 2 sp.  Squamates – lizards & snakes – ~7900 sp. http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizar ds-new- zealand/tuatara/tuatara.htm https://www.floridamuseum.ufl.edu/her petology/fl-snakes/visual-id/ Lepidosaurs – tuataras (Sphenodontians)  Tuatara relatives ~ 220 MYA, many continents, up to 1m long.  Now - 30 islands off New Zealand  Humans arrived NZ 750 years ago – Rats – Ate eggs, eliminated tuataras on main islands.  Remaining sp. ~50cm – Eat insects, small lizards, bird eggs, chicks – Survival depends on islands staying rat-free. http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizards-new- zealand/tuatara/tuatara.htm https://www .youtube.co m/watch?v= 2xg18zNbCL s Lepidosaurs – lizards  Most lizards small – Jaragua lizard (Dominican Republic, 2001) 16mm long. – Komodo dragon (Indonesia) ~ 3m  Hunts deer, etc – pathogenic bacteria with bite + “venom”?  Stalks wounded prey. http://www.youtube .com/watch?v=QOF 4YPdYELg&NR=1 https://www.newscientist.com/article/ dn1635-minute-gecko-matches- smallest-reptile-record/ Mark Dumont - Flickr: There Be Dragons, CC BY 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?cur id=25935468 Lepidosaurs – snakes  Legless  Some sp. vestigial pelvic & limb bones.  Movement – Normal, sidewinding & concertina - lateral bending – Rectilinear - grips ground with belly scales http://www.youtube.c om/watch?v=OSaHdeK eR7k https://www.floridamuseum.ufl.edu/her petology/fl-snakes/visual-id/ Lepidosaurs – snakes  Carnivorous - adaptations – Chemical receptors – No eardrums – Sensitive to ground vibrations – Heat detecting organs in pit vipers – Some sp. venomous  hollow/grooved teeth – Tongue – fan odours to olfactory organs  Jacobson’s organ – Kinetic skull & elastic skin. http://reptilis.net/serpentes/eating.html Turtles (Testudines)  Anapsid – no temporal fenestra.  Box-like shell - fused vertebrae, clavicles & ribs – carapace & plastron.  307 sp. Most - hard shell – defence.  Earliest turtle fossils ~ 220 MYA – Fully formed shells.  Absence transitional fossils – origin turtle shell – molecular data – Turtles related to crocodilians & other plated Triassic archosaurs https://www.floridamuseum.u fl.edu/event/world-sea-turtle- day/ http://www.tortoises.com/?f https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_so ftshell_turtle Turtles (Testudines)  Earliest turtles could not retract heads – Retraction mechanisms evolved independently - 2 branches  Pleurodires – fold neck horizontally  Cryptodires – fold neck vertically  Terrestrial & aquatic sp.  Human impact – Fishing nets – Habitat destruction – Pollution – Climate change - TSD http://ww w.youtube .com/watc h?v=0ymrr zjaDIQ https://www.slideshare.net/alvinworks2006/what-is-a-turtle Alligators, Crocodiles & Gharials  Collectively called crocodilians – emerged Triassic – 23 extant sp.  Early crocodilians – Small, terrestrial quadrupeds – long slender legs – later adapted to aquatic habitats  Upturned nostrils  Some Mesozoic sp. ~12m – attacked dinosaurs? https://www.thegoavilla.com/g oa/distanation/goa- crocodiles.html http://www.wilbord.com/es/universidad_autonoma_de_ madrid.php Origin of birds  Cladistic analysis fossils – birds – bipedal saurischians – theropods.  Late 1990s – feathered theropod fossils – China.  Feathers evolved before powered flight  Functions?  Insulation, camouflage?  Courtship, brooding? https://www.amnh.org/lea rn/pd/dinos/markmeetsda ve.html https://www.scientificamerican.com/gallery/feathered-t-rex-kin/ https://www. scientificame rican.com/ga llery/feathere d-t-rex-kin/ Evolution of flight in theropods?  Ground up (cursorial) or trees down (arboreal) hypotheses?  Feathers enabled small running dinosaurs - gain lift - aids predatory lifestyle?  Dinosaurs climbed trees & glided aided by feathers? http://edition.cnn.com/2003/TECH/ science/01/18/coolsc.coolsc.primitiv e/index.html http://astronomy.nmsu.edu/ Origin of birds  By 150 MYA feathered theropods - birds.  Archaeopteryx (Germany 1861) – Feathered wings – Ancestral characters – teeth, clawed digits in wings & long tail. – Flew well – high speeds, but not standing take off.  Later Cretaceous bird fossils – lost teeth & clawed forelimbs – acquired short feathered tail. http://www.dinosaur fact.net/jurassic/Arch aeopteryx.php Birds  10,000 extant sp.  Birds - archosaurs.  Derived characters of birds & modifications for flight – No urinary bladder – Females most sp. – 1 ovary. – Small gonads – except breeding season. – Toothless – reduced head weight. – Wings  Feathers - β-keratin – aerofoil & aerodynamics. http://www.okbirds.com/?cat=29 http://birdsimage.net/kiwi-bird- images-facts/kiwi-bird-eat-photo/ Advantages of flight  Enhances hunting/scavenging  Escape predators  Migration – food /breeding sites  But… energetically expensive – metabolism – Birds – endothermic – Feathers (& fat in some sp.) – insulation – Lungs – tubes to elastic air sacs – improve respiration – Circulatory system – 4 chambered heart – Supports high metabolic rate. Extant birds  28 extant orders – clade Neornithes – Evidence clade 65.5 MYA  Variety of forms  Ratites (O. Struthioniformes) – flightless – ostrich, rhea, kiwi, emu, etc. – Sternal keel absent & small pectoral muscles.  O. Sphenisciformes – flightless penguins – powerful pectoral muscles. http://birdsimage.net/kiwi-bird- images-facts/kiwi-bird-eat-photo/ Adrian Pingstone (Arpingstone) - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=5074712 https://www.emperor- penguin.com/aptenodytes- forsteriis.html Extant birds  Some flightless sp. rails, ducks & pigeons.  Demands of flight – similar body shapes  But…  Beak shape adaptations – diet.  Variation in foot structure – perching, defence, swimming, walking, running, climbing, food handling & courtship. http://www.youtube.com/w atch?v=SAz1L8DlvBM http://people.eku.edu/ritchisong/birddigestion.html Summary  Importance of the amniotic egg  Evolutionary origins & trends in the reptilian clade: – Reptiles & birds .
